translated: Jātaka
Ten-&-Twelve
The Four Gates
The Lesser Bodhi Jātaka
“You who have taken away
this dear one who speaks kindly,
having seized her by force,
what will you do, brahmin?”
“If it arose in me, it would not be released,
it would not be released as long as I live;
like a large cloud of dust,
I would quickly drive it away.”
“What you boasted about before,
as if you had no strength,
today you are silent,
you are stroking your outer robe.”
“What arose in me was not released,
it was not released as long as I live;
like a large cloud of dust,
I quickly drove it away.”
“What arose in you that was not released,
what was not released as long as you live;
like a large cloud of dust,
which did you drive away?”
“What is born that one does not see,
when unborn, one sees well;

analyzed: saḥ me uppajji na u mucci
translated: that arose in me but was not released,
anger, the domain of the foolish.
By what is born enemies rejoice,
seeking suffering,

analyzed: saḥ me uppajji na u mucci
translated: that arose in me but was not released,
Anger is the domain of the foolish.
And when it arises in me,
I do not understand what is for my own good.

analyzed: saḥ me uppajji na u mucci
translated: It arises in me but does not let go,

original: kodho dummedhagocaro.🔽Yenābhibhūto kusalaṁ jahāti,🔽Parakkare vipulañcāpi atthaṁ;
analyzed: kodhaḥ dummedha gocaraḥ  yena abhibhūtaḥ kusalam jahāti  parakkare vipulañca api attha
translated: Anger is the domain of the foolish.🔽When overcome by anger one abandons what is wholesome,
And even great benefits that are at hand,

analyzed: kodhaḥ mahā rāja na me amuccatha
translated: Then anger, O great king, does not let go of me,🔽That powerful and fearful army.
When wood is being consumed,
Fire is born;
It burns that very wood,
Since it is born from it.
Thus in a dull person,
A fool who does not understand,
Anger is born from agitation,
And he is burned by it.🔽Just as fire spreads
In grass and wood,🔽So does the fame of one

original: kodho yassa pavaḍḍhati;🔽Nihīyati tassa yaso,🔽kāḷapakkheva candimā.
analyzed: kodhaḥ yassa pavaḍḍhati  nihīyati tassa yasaḥ  kāḷapakkhā iva candimā
translated: In whom anger increases.🔽Just as the moon in the dark fortnight🔽Wanes,
So does the fame of one
In whom anger increases.🔽Just as the moon in the bright fortnight🔽Grows,

analyzed: āpūrati tassa yasaḥ  sukka pakkhā iva candimā ti
translated: So does the fame of one
In whom anger is pacified.🔽The Cūḷabodhi Jātaka is the fifth.
